prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Arguments rejected by the Panel—Possibility of adverse rulings

para.paratext: The Panel has openly stated that it would not consider the possibility of adverse rulings by the transferee court in determining whether transfer should be ordered.[1] This ruling is consistent with the judiciary's traditional opposition to tactics designed merely to permit forum-or judge-shopping. In one case the Panel observed:

[T]he prospect of an unfavorable ruling by the transferee court or the possibility that another district judge may be more favorably disposed to a litigant's contentions are clearly not factors considered by the Panel in determining whether transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is appropriate.[2]

The Panel has also declined to consider the likely rulings of possible transferee judges in selecting a transferee court or transferee judge. Similarly, the Panel will not anticipate or presume that the transferee court will abuse its discretion or enter inappropriate or unfavorable rulings,[3] (although many rulings are unfavorable to some party) or misapply the law.[4] The Panel is not the appropriate forum to challenge the bias or prejudice of a trial judge, and the Panel will not permit a transfer motion to be a vehicle for considering such matters.[5]

The Panel has also explicitly rejected this factor as a basis for retransferring actions. In one case the plaintiffs in actions that had been originally transferred by the Panel sought re transfer of the original actions so they could proceed separately in a different district.[6] The Panel denied retransfer because the plaintiffs had simply argued that the transferee court had prejudiced their position by failing to grant sufficient time for discovery and by refusing to allow them to pursue individual patent infringement issues separately from and prior to the common issues.[7]

The Panel has also rejected consideration of the transferee court's probable application of the, choice of law rules as a factor in deciding whether to order' transfer. This factor is discussed in greater detail in § 5:52.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See In re: Equifax, Inc., Customer Data Security Breach Litigation, 289 F. Supp. 3d 1322, 1325 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017); In re Payment Card Interchange Fee and Merchant Discount Antitrust Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Beef Industry Antitrust Litigation, 419 F. Supp. 720 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Suess Patent Infringement Litigation, 384 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1974); In re Glenn W. Turner Enterprises Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 805 (J.P.M.L. 1973); In re 7-Eleven Franchise Antitrust Litigation, 358 F. Supp. 286 (J.P.M.L. 1973); In re Texas Gulf Sulphur Securities Litigation, 344 F. Supp. 1398 (J.P.M.L. 1972); In re Motion Picture “Standard Accessories” and “Pre-Vues” Antitrust Litigation, 339 F. Supp. 1278 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
See In re Texas Gulf Sulphur Securities Litigation, 344 F. Supp. 1398, 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
See In re Plumbing Fixtures Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 756, 758 (J.P.M.L. 1972) (Panel would not assume transferee court would apply law of wrong circuit).
In re Plumbing Fixtures, 332 F. Supp. 1047, 1048 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
See In re Molinaro/Catanzaro Patent Litigation, 402 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
